summary: This is a memorandum from the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) to the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) providing a status update on the BOP's response to eight recommendations from the OIG's final report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The OIG analyzes the BOP's reported actions and determines whether each recommendation is resolved or requires further action.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the OIG investigation and the recommendations in this memorandum.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons provided a status update to the OIG in response to the eight recommendations from the June 26, 2023, report.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: The document references that a lack of a contingency plan for cellmate assignment increased the likelihood Epstein would not have been housed alone at the time of his death, implying the event of his suicide.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's investigation found a lack of a contingency plan (e.g., a list of alternate cellmates) contributed to Jeffrey Epstein being housed alone at the time of his death.
The BOP's response to Recommendation 2 was deemed non-responsive by the OIG, as it did not address the need for continuity of cellmate assignment or a contingency plan for reassignment.
The BOP is developing a CEO memo to provide guidance on housing and cellmate procedures for inmates following suicide watch or psychological observation.
The BOP is updating Program Statement 5500.14, the Correctional Services Procedures Manual, to address several of the OIG's recommendations regarding inmate accountability and procedures.
The BOP has implemented recruitment and retention incentives, including a $10,000 or 25% salary recruitment bonus for new Correctional Officers, to address staffing shortages.
